11.title: Bursting Balloons
11.author: by Al Hormel
11.appears_in: p. 28-31 in Hogan's Alley, v. 1, no. 4 (1997).
notes: (Bursting Balloons)

Column of various complaints, among others that most strips should not be reprinted in complete collections, that original art should not be donated to libraries, that four different cartoonists have been named Frank Miller, and that some cartoonists are too good for the medium.

12.title: Bursting Balloons
12.author: by Al Hormel
12.appears_in: p. 26-29 in Hogan's Alley, v. 2, no. 1 (=no. 5) (1998).
notes: (Bursting Balloons)

Summary: Describes the success of artists who have taken over established comic strips, including Bud Sagendorf and Bobby London (Popeye), Jim Raymond, Stan Drake and Denis LeBrun (Blondie), Dick Moores and Jim Scancarelli (Gasoline Alley), Leonard Starr (Annie), Selby Kelly (Pogo), George Wunder (Terry and the Pirates), Jerry Scott and Guy and Brad Gilchrist (Nancy)

13.title: Bursting Ballons
13.author: by Al Hormel
13.appears_in: p. 24-26 in Hogan's Alley, v. 2, no. 3 (=no. 7) (1999).
notes: (Bursting Balloons)
Column on newspaper strips in New York in the 1930s, and on Al Capp and Li'l Abner. -

14.title: Bursting Balloons
14.author: by Al Hormel
14.appears_in: p. 24, 26-27 in Hogan's Alley, v. 2, no. 4 (=no. 8) (2000).
notes: (Bursting Balloons)
Column on Peanuts, with short sections on strips adapted to radio and television, on For Better or For Worse, and on New Yorker cartoons.

15.title: Bursting Balloons
15.author: by Al Hormel
15.series: 2001) "The Good, the Bad and the Hideous"
15.appears_in: p. 26-28 in Hogan's Alley, no. 9 (=v. 3, no. 1) (Summer 2001).
notes: (Bursting Ballons)
Summary: General comments about the art of comic strips, showing samples with discussion of the work of Charles Payne on S'Matter Pop and Art Huhta on Mescal Ike.

16.title: Bursting Balloons
16.author: by Al Hormel
16.appears_in: p. 29-32 in Hogan's Alley, no. 10 (=v. 3, no. 2) (Summer 2002).
notes: (Bursting Balloons)
"Any serious comics fan has accumulated a list of favorites. Al Hormel takes us on a tour of his."

132.title: "Burying the Treasure"
132.author: [No author]
132.series: Cactus Canyon) p. 30-34 in Treasure Chest of Fun and Fact, v. 4, no. 9
notes: Begins: "When her treasure code was accidentally devoured by a hungry billy goat, Betsy Bell was brokenhearted. She thought it lost forever until, to her surprise, she found a copy which had been hidden away by one of the ranch cowboys! Puzzled as to what she should do about it, she rode at once to the mission for a talk with her good friend, Father Valentine."
"To be continued."
